title: Confirm Se (Dominant)
intro: Answer based on your long-term patterns. Use 4–5 only if it’s consistently true across years and contexts. Se-dominant is about staying open to life through direct engagement with what’s real and happening now (action, experience, immediate feedback), not just liking parties or sports.

items.text: I trust real-time experience more than speculation. I prefer to test, try, and adjust instead of overthinking possibilities.
examples: When unsure, I’d rather do a quick trial than keep debating in my head.
I make progress by acting and correcting, not by perfect planning.
Seeing/handling the real thing changes my view more than theory does.
I feel calmer once I can interact with the situation directly.

items.text: I feel most alive when I’m engaged with the environment (movement, activity, challenge, interaction). Too much stillness makes me restless.
examples: If nothing is happening, I get bored and want to ‘do something’.
My mood improves when I get into motion or into the action.
I dislike long periods of waiting with no stimulation or feedback.
I naturally seek something engaging when my energy drops.

items.text: I say “yes” to opportunities easily when they promise experience. The value is the experience itself, not just a future payoff.
examples: If something sounds fun/engaging, I want to jump in.
I decide fast when there’s a clear chance to participate.
I’d rather take a good opportunity now than save it for a perfect plan.
I feel annoyed when people block action with endless discussion.

items.text: I’m good at adapting on the fly. When conditions change, I respond quickly without needing a full mental map first.
examples: I can improvise and stay effective when plans break.
I notice what’s actually happening and adjust immediately.
I’m comfortable with uncertainty if I can interact with it directly.
I prefer flexible action over rigid structure.

items.text: Restrictions on my movement/choices often trigger an immediate urge to push back or find a workaround.
examples: My first reaction to heavy rules is ‘there must be a way around this.’
I feel trapped when I can’t explore, act, or engage freely.
I dislike being micromanaged in how I do things.
I regain energy when I reclaim freedom of action.

items.text: People sometimes describe me as impulsive, intense, or “too much in the moment,” even when I see it as simply engaging with life.
examples: Others say I jump in too fast or don’t think enough first.
I’ve been told I chase stimulation or excitement.
People call me blunt/direct because I respond to what’s happening now.
I get labeled ‘spontaneous’ or ‘hard to predict’.

items.text: High stimulation (noise, crowds, chaos, sensory intensity) quickly drains me, and I avoid it most of the time.
examples: I need frequent quiet breaks in lively places.
Too much activity makes me shut down rather than feel energized.
I prefer calm, controlled settings as my default.
I often feel overloaded by the environment.

items.text: I naturally focus on hidden meaning, long-range implications, or what things ‘symbolize’ more than what’s happening right now.
examples: I often read between the lines and search for deeper meaning first.
I get stuck thinking about implications instead of acting.
I prefer interpretation and theory to direct engagement.
I replay conversations to decode motives.

items.text: I strongly prefer rules, certainty, and safe structure; I avoid risk even when the potential experience is attractive.
examples: I feel uneasy unless I have clear procedures and permission.
I’d rather miss out than deal with uncertainty or risk.
I rarely act without having everything planned.
I value predictability more than exploration.

items.text: I’m more excited by abstract ideas and impractical possibilities than by concrete experiences and real-world feedback.
examples: I prefer brainstorming over hands-on participation.
I like talking about possibilities more than doing them.
I often ignore concrete evidence if the idea feels interesting.
I chase novelty mainly in concepts, not in lived experience.
